trail.content_raw:
Okay, wow! This movie was unbelievable! Remember how we can all pretty much agree that The Last Jedi had moments that kinda fell flat?  Well, I think I figured out the reason why.  It was because they were putting all their effort into this movie.  Now, just to warn everyone- because this is a review, I WILL be spoiling the plot of this movie.  So if you plan on reading beyond this point before you actually go see the movie yourself, then that’s on you.

[[MORE]]

The movie opens on some run-down planet called Corellia, where this giant sentient millipede-like alien called Lady Proxima essentially runs the show.  Because of the corruption that now runs rampant after the formation of the Galactic Empire, a lot of crime syndicates have been able to take root, and Lady Proxima is no exception.  She runs this thieves guild on Corellia where she basically abducts children and forces them to steal stuff for her in exchange for food and shelter. Right away, we are shown that the teenaged Han is one of the young thieves under Lady Proxima’s control. Unfortunately, the latest mission he was sent on, which involved delivering a cache of coaxium, a highly valued kind of fuel in exchange for money, didn’t exactly go well and he was forced to run for his life, leaving the money he was supposed to retrieve behind. However, he did manage to swipe a small vial of coaxium for himself.  He shows this to his girlfriend, Qi'ra, who also lives under Lady Proxima’s thumb. Han states that he plans to trade the vial of coaxium for passage off Corellia for the both of them, so they can live in freedom.  Han also reveals his aspiration to be a top-notch pilot with his own ship, a goal he plans to achieve once he and Qi’ra escape Corellia and Lady Proxima.

Before Han could put his plan into action, however Lady Proxima’s goons appear, apprehending Han.  He’s forcibly taken before Lady Proxima, who is not pleased that Han failed his most recent mission by not bringing her the money he was supposed to pick up.  As punishment for his transgression, she is all set to have him whipped and beaten until he learns his lesson and starts being completely obedient to her.  This prompts Qi’ra to try and come to his defense, but Han comes up with a plan on the spot.  He threatens to blow everyone up with a thermal detonator that he just happened to have on him.  (Which was an obvious callback to that one scene in Return of the Jedi.  You all know the one I mean.)  Of course, Lady Proxima isn’t stupid and realizes that Han is just holding a rock. But Han just basically shrugs and hurls the rock up at the roof, which creates a large hole that sunlight pours through.  Lady Proxima, it turns out, does not like the light, as contact with the sunlight will give her an instant sunburn, and thus has no choice but to retreat into her water-filled chamber.

Taking advantage of the resulting turmoil, Han grabs hold of Qi’ra and the pair attempt to make their getaway, utilizing a land speeder Han had commandeered in the first scene of the movie.  After a whole car chase scene, Han and Qi’ra manage to make it to Corellia’s spaceport, which is filled with people trying to make it off the planet by boarding a transport that’s scheduled to leave soon.  Right away, it’s established that this is a risky place to be, as a lot of the people there are trying to sneak off the planet to freedom, with Imperial Guards and Stormtroopers standing at the ready to apprehend people who don’t have the proper documentation.  At one point, we even see a group of children being forcibly separated from their parents. (Not sure if this was meant to be taken as social commentary with political subtext, but it was still unsettling to witness.)  Trying to act casual, Han and Qi’ra get into the ticket agent line, all too aware of the fact that Lady Proxima’s goons are searching the premises for them.  When it’s their turn to present their travel papers to the Imperial Guard on duty, Han admits they don’t have any, but manages to bribe the guard with the vial of coaxium, stating that they’ll hand it over to her if they’re allowed through the gates.  Unable to resist the bribe, the Imperial Guard opens the gate to allow them through.  But just as the pair are in the process of walking through the gate, Lady Proxima’s goons appear out of nowhere and apprehend Qi’ra, just as the gates slam shut. As such, she and Han are forcibly separated, and Han can only watch as Qi’ra is dragged off.  As she’s taken away, Han calls out to her, vowing that he will come back for her as soon as he can.

However, before he can uphold his promise, Han realizes that he’s going to need a ship of his own.  In the hopes of earning enough money to purchase a ship, he ends up volunteering to join the Empire by enlisting in Imperial Navy.  When he goes to the recruitment office, he confesses to the Imperial Recruitment Officer that he has no surname.  As such, the Recruitment Officer decides to give him the name Han Solo.

The action then fast-forwards to three years later.  Han is now serving as an infantryman and is placed among an Imperial squadron fighting on an extremely muddy planet called Mimban.  It comes out that he was kicked out of the Imperial Flight Academy due to an inability to follow orders without question.  Now, it might just have been me, but for some reason, the whole battlefront on Mimban made me think of World War One, and the whole trench warfare they utilized.  Though I’m not sure if that was intentional.

While he’s on Mimban, Han spots a small group among the infantrymen.  Right away, he is able to surmise that they’re actually impostors who infiltrated the infantry in order to steal one of the dropships, particularly when one of them doesn’t seem to realize that his uniform indicates he’s the highest ranking soldier among them until it’s directly pointed out to him. Han ends up confronting them about this, attempting to blackmail them into letting him join them when they make their way off the planet.  However, the leader of the group, Tobias Beckett, ends up having Han arrested for attempted desertion instead, telling the arresting officers that Han is a liar and that they shouldn’t believe a word he says.  Which pretty much takes care of Han’s threats to expose them as impostors.

The arresting officers sentence Han to be fed to the ‘beast’ they have been keeping imprisoned.  When Han is tossed into grate covered pit, it’s revealed, to nobody’s shock, that the ‘beast’ is actually Chewbacca.  Initially, Chewbacca doesn’t hesitate to attack Han, possibly embittered by how long the Imperial Army has kept him starved and chained up.  But he instantly relents when Han reveals that he can speak Wookiee.  At least, to an extent.  Han isn’t exactly fluent in Chewbacca’s native language, but he knows enough to convey his plan of escape to Chewbacca.  Han’s plan involves them staging a fight for the entertainment of the Imperial Officers that are overseeing the proceedings. But instead of punching Han, Chewbacca will be hitting the support beam that is holding up the grate covering the opening of the pit.  The plan ultimately succeeds, enabling Han and Chewbacca to climb out.  But the pair are still chained together, which leads to a brief argument of which direction they’ll head off in. In the end, Han convinces Chewbacca to trust him, stating that he has friends that are in the process of leaving Mimban.  All they have to do is continue their alliance long enough reach their shuttle before they leave.  After that, they’d be free to go their separate ways at any time.  Chewbacca ends up agreeing to that plan, and two hurry off to try and catch up to Tobias and his team.  They arrive at the launch pad just in time to see Tobias’ ship taking off, but when Tobias and his allies see that Han has managed to get away, and is now accompanied by a Wookiee, it’d decided that they will allow the pair to board the ship.  More specifically, Tobias and the group’s Alien member, Rio, (who apparently has a deep appreciation for Wookiees) decide it’s a good idea.  The female of the trio, Val, isn’t exactly on board with admitting a pair of rookies into their operation, but she ultimately goes along with it, realizing that she’s outvoted.

Now that Han and Chewbacca have joined Tobias’ team, they are informed of their plan to pull off a train heist in order to make off with a shipment of that fuel source, coaxium.  The night before their heist, the group has this whole campfire bonding moment, with Han stating that his ultimate goal is still the same as it was at the start of the movie.  He wants to earn enough money to buy a ship, so he can return to Corellia and save Qi’ra. This scene also serves to inform the audience that, after the rise of the Galactic Empire, the Imperial Forces managed to overthrow Kashyyyk, and a good number of Wookiees were taken prisoner. It’s stated that Chewbacca’s family, or at least his tribe, were among the captured Wookies, so his ultimate goal is to find them and free them.  Apart from those character development moments, nothing much else happens during this scene.  But it is indicated that Tobias and Val are romantically involved.

The following morning, Han, Chewbacca, Tobias, Val and Rio proceed with their train heist. However, the robbery is interrupted by the appearance of a band of space pirates called the Cloud Riders, who are led by an armored figure known as Enfys Nest.  This leads to a whole action sequence, in which both groups try to claim the coaxium.  Due in part to the interference of the Cloud Riders, Val and Rio are both killed. And, when Han, Tobias and Chewbacca try to make off with the spoils, Han ends up defying Tobias orders and releases the cargo, resulting in it getting destroyed.  This was because the Cloud Riders also had attached tethers to the crate of coaxium, resulting in them having a tug-of-war of sorts.  And Han realized that if he didn’t release their hold on the coaxium, then he wouldn’t be able to maneuver their ship around a mountain in time.  So it was pretty much a choice between the coaxium and their lives.  Honestly, I think that decision was very much in character for Han.  Isn’t that what will one day get him into trouble with Jabba?

On a side note, I have to admit I really liked Rio.  I thought he was a fun character, especially with his strange love for Wookiees.  It was a bit like Maz from the new trilogy. The moment he first appeared, I instantly decided that I liked him.  So it really stinks that he was killed off after such a short amount of screentime. Shame we couldn’t see more of him.

In the aftermath of the failed heist, Tobias rounds on Han, angrily punching him for losing the coaxium.  Here, it’s revealed that Tobias and his late teammates weren’t actually stealing the coaxium for themselves.  Instead, they had been hired by Drydon Vos, the leader of a criminal syndicate known as the Crimson Dawn.  Now that the crate of coaxium is lost, Tobias is fearful for his life, as Drydon Vos is not known to be very understanding or forgiving.  And he knows that he won’t be able to run, as Drydon Vos would undoubtedly succeed in locating him, no matter where he might try to hide.  In the hopes of convincing Drydon Vos to give him another chance, Tobias ends up going to seek an audience with him on the mob boss’ space yacht.  But before he leaves, Tobias informs Han and Chewbacca that this will be their last chance to get out of this mess.  Because Drydon Vos currently has no idea that either of them even exist and will never know they were even involved with this if they back out now.  But Han insists on seeing this through to the end, as he knows he can’t pass up on this chance to get the money for this job.  Chewbacca also agrees to stick around.  Maybe because he feels that this would eventually help him locate the other Wookiees that were abducted and taken away from Kashyyyk.

When they arrive at Drydon Vos’ space yacht, Tobias announces their presence to one of Drydon Vos’ goons.  While waiting around to be summoned, Tobias and Chewbacca head off to get some drinks at the bar while Han decides to make his way to the edge of the crowd to simply look out the window.  But then, someone approaches him and taps his shoulder.  To Han’s shock and amazement, he sees the person who has joined him at the window is none other than Qi’ra, his girlfriend from Corellia!  Han is overjoyed to see her again, and he immediately starts to apologize for not coming back for her, stating that he really had planned on doing so the moment he’d been able to buy his own ship.  But Qi’ra waves away his apology, stating that it’s all in the past and she doesn’t resent him for not being able to keep his promise to her, also pointing out that he would have been killed if he hadn’t taken advantage of his chance to get off Corellia.  It turns out that, after she and Han were separated three years ago, Qi’ra somehow became entangled into the Crimson Dawn and is essentially bound to Drydon Vos now.

But the two are not given much of a chance to catch up, because that’s when Tobias returns, announcing their meeting with Drydon Vos has been approved.  Needless to say, Drydon Vos is not pleased when he finds out Tobias did not bring the shipment of coaxium that he’d requested and is all set to kill him for this, unless Tobias can tell him exactly how he plans to make it up to him.  Tobias therefore offers to locate and steal some coaxium from a different source.  Of course, this is easier said than done as coaxium is still super-rare, with the Empire holding a cartel on the market. But Han has an idea- they go right to the source and steal unprocessed coaxium from the mines on the planet Kessel. Of course, this is an extremely risky plan, as unprocessed coaxium is extremely volatile, and if it’s not processed within a certain time frame, then it will explode.  Once again, however, Han has an idea.  There’s apparently a processing plant that’s not controlled by the Empire, located on the planet Savareen.  Although this plan is still extremely risky, as it would require them to make the infamous Kessel Run in less than twenty parsecs.  And yes, I know that a parsec is a unit of distance and not time.  But maybe the implication is that the average Kessel Run spans a distance that’s over twenty parsecs, and to make the journey in less than twenty parsects is synonymous with finding a way to travel from Maine to California (a trip that should span 3,247 miles) in only 1,000 miles.  But then again, this is just me trying to make sense over a line that was probably only meant to give nerds something to harp on.

In any event, Drydon Vos ultimately agrees to Han’s plan and, in what I’m guessing was an attempt to make sure that Tobias, Han and Chewbacca follow through and don’t just try to run, he has Qi’ra accompany them.  But before they can go off to steal the coaxium, they have to locate a suitably fast ship that would enable them to make the trip. Fortunately, Qi’ra knows where to find such a ship.  She leads the group to this place on a snowy planet called Vandor that kinda looks like a crashed luxury starship that has been converted into a gambling hall. There, they encounter the smooth-talking Lando Calrissian, who boasts that his ship is the fastest one in existence. He’s accompanied by L3-37, a female Piloting Droid that Lando apparently had custom made to be his co-pilot. While I’m sure some people might disagree with me on this, I say L3 was the best character in this movie.  Her claim to fame was the fact that she’s a fierce advocate for Droid rights.  When we first meet her, she’s angrily protesting a Droid battle ring that’s being held in the gambling hall, trying to reason with one of the Droids being used in the fighting and then getting into an argument with the Droid’s owner.   To be honest, I totally see her point in regards to her crusade.  Even though Droids are clearly manmade, they are still programed with artificial intelligence, and they all seem to have their own personalities.  It does present an interesting debate over what it means to be considered ‘alive.’ And when you think of it, there does seem to be a prevailing discrimination towards Droids.  For instance, it seems like a lot of eateries won’t serve Droids.  And then there’s Obi-Wan’s comment in Attack of the Clones, in which he more or less stated that he didn’t thing Droids were capable of independent thought.  So, it could be argued that Droids are largely treated as robot slaves in the Star Wars universe, with each type of Droid being automatically assigned a particular task from the moment they’re activated and never given the opportunity to rise above the task they were issued upon their creation.  For instance, I don’t recall seeing any Droids serving on the Galactic Senate during the prequel trilogy.

Anyway, Han approaches Lando, with Tobias, Chewbacca and Qi’ra watching with the rest of the crowd, to ask him about his ship.  Lando states he won it in a game of Sabacc, which is basically this world’s equivalent to poker.  Han kinda chuckles at that, vocally wondering what kind of man bets his ship in a card game. Eventually, he asks to be dealt into the game of Sabacc that Lando is currently playing with a handful of Aliens. Now, the build up to this moment is rather strange.  Because before this scene, we had been given no sort of context as to what Han’s gambling skill is like.  Is he actually really good when it comes to gambling?  Has he ever gambled or played Sabacc before?  But I guess he’s quite good, because he manages to stay in the game after everyone else has folded.  So, in the end, it’s just him against Lando.  In the final round, Lando ends up wagering his ship, which, of course, ends up being the Millennium Falcon.  To counter this wager, Han also bets his own ship.  Which we know doesn’t actually exist.  However, Lando ends up winning the game because he was cheating by hiding a stash of cards up his sleeve.  After the game, Lando approaches the group to ask where he can pick up the ship he supposedly won off of Han.  Only to be told that it wasn’t there.   As a consolation prize, they fill him in on their plan to steal unprocessed coaxium from the mines on Kessel.  They tell Lando that if he provides his ship for the heist, then they will give him a cut of the money they’ll get for the coaxium.  Lando doesn’t seem to be completely thrilled with this arrangement, but he ultimately agrees to it, especially when he sees Tobias is involved. Apparently, Tobias had previously brought about the death of somebody Lando owed a lot of money to, so Lando is grateful towards him for indirectly freeing him from his debt.

And they’re off to Kessel.  Along the way, we get a few scenes of the characters just being characters.  Qi’ra is exploring the Falcon, finding that Lando seems to have a thing for capes.  She also has a moment with Han which leads to them passionately making out, only for them to be interrupted by Tobias, who counsels Han that he’d do well to not trust Qi’ra so much, and that it’s best to just expect everyone might betray him.  Tobias and Chewbacca also play around with that holographic chess board thing (with Chewbacca losing, much to his frustration.)  And we also get a whole ‘girl talk’ moment with Qi’ra and L3, with L3 observing that Han is still in love with Qi’ra.  It’s at this point that we’re told that Lando and L3’s relationship is a bit more than just one between pilot and co-pilot, and it’s heavily implied they have a sexual relationship.  So I guess Lando is pansexual?  Okay, that’s pretty interesting.  I don’t think we see many pansexual characters featured in the media, do we?

Eventually, they reach Kessel and, in order to infiltrate the mine, Qi’ra, Tobias and L3 masquerade as human traffickers and present Han and Chewbacca as new workers for the mine.  And you might notice that Tobias is wearing the same disguise Lando will eventually wear in the first half of Return of the Jedi.  Speaking of Lando, he’s apparently hanging back on the Millennium Falcon to make another entry in his personal ‘Lando Chronicles.’  I guess we’re supposed to conclude that Lando is a bit full of himself.

Upon being brought into the mines, Han and Chewbacca both reveal that their restraints were not locked, and they immediately break free and overpower the two guards bringing them down the mine elevator  (with Chewbacca actually ripping off somebody’s arms.)  Meanwhile, up in the control room, Qi’ra gets to work on upholding her part of the plan, which involves her and Tobias taking out the mine foreman and guards so L3 could take over the control room’s console, in order to gain access to the mine’s security footage and use that to direct Han and Chewbacca to the chamber the coaxium is stored in.  However, in the process, L3 finds she can’t stand to turn a blind eye to the fact that Droids are being used to run the mine, especially when she spots a restraining bolt affixed to one of the Astromech Droids. She ends up starting a complete riot by getting the Droids to free one other, which leads to all the other mine workers rising up and attempting to fight their way to freedom.  Thankfully, this creates a distraction that makes it possible for Han to locate the coaxium vault.  Amidst the resulting turmoil, Han starts to wheel them out to the Millennium Falcon.  Chewbacca, on the other hand, briefly went off on his own when he spots some Wookiees laboring in the mines because he recognized them as some of the Wookiees that were captured alongside him.  But he ends up rejoining Han just in time to help him get the coaxium to the Millennium Falcon, with the other Wookiees helping load the canisters onto the ship. And, when given the choice between staying with his Wookiee brethren or sticking with Han and the others, Chewbacca ultimately chooses the latter.  Most likely because he’s grown to genuinely consider Han as a friend.

This whole prison break/coaxium heist quickly shifts into a huge gun battle as the mine workers try to escape.  During the fight, L3 gets gunned down and Lando is also hit when he runs out to retrieve her. Sadly, while Lando only ends up with an injured shoulder, L3 is damaged beyond repair and ends up dying in Lando’s arms.  

With Lando out of commission and L3 gone, Han and Chewbacca (who admits to have gained some piloting experience during the 190 years he’s been alive) are the only ones capable of flying the ship away from Kessel.  Unfortunately, their path back to Savareen is being blocked by an Imperial brigade, led by a Star Destroyer that immediately sends a fleet of TIE Fighters at them.  It’s speculated that the Imperial patrol had heard about the uprising on Kessel and had come to put an end to it.  While they eventually manage to get rid of the TIE Fighters, through a combination of Tobias manning the ship’s gun and a risky move by Han, they realize they lost a considerable amount of time, as the coaxium is already starting to destabilize. In a desperate attempt at making it to Savareen in time, Han suggests taking a short cut through a cloudy ‘tunnel’ inside the nebula cloud they’re traveling past.  At first, everyone feels this is crazy, as entering that cloud tunnel would most likely kill them, as it contains a high number of plasma storms. But Han points out that their current position is no better.  In order to try and increase their chances at making through alive, it’s decided to install the memory banks/navigational archives of L3 into the Millennium Falcon’s motherboard.  It was established earlier that L3 was programed with impeccable navigational skills. Once L3’s programing is fully installed within the Millennium Falcon, they are able to navigate their way through the nebula cloud tunnel, despite some trouble with a Space Kraken and a black hole of some kind.  They evade the Space Kraken by launching off the Millennium Falcon’s escape pod to create a diversion (which explains why the front of the ship wound up with that recognizable shape.)  And to escape the black hole, they use a single drop of the coaxium to power the ship’s fusion reactor resulting in the Millennium Falcon getting a major speed boost that frees it from the pull of the black hole

Finally, they manage to make it to Savareen.  And thanks to Han’s plan to travel through the nebula cloud and L3’s memory within the Millennium Falcon, they made the Kessel Run in 12 parsects. While they’re getting the coaxium processed, and for Drydon Vos to arrive, Han and Qi’ra have another scene together.  Han tries to convince Qi’ra to come away with him when this is all over, but Qi’ra tells him that’s not possible due to her involvement with the Crimson Dawn.  I guess the implication is that the Crimson Dawn is like the Mafia- once you’re in it, you’re in it for life.  She tells Han that his feelings for her would change if he had any inking of the things she’s done as part of the Crimson Dawn. Which I guess is meant to imply that she was utilized as their hit woman, tasked with brutally murdering anyone they ordered her to.  If that’s the case, I can see why Qi’ra wouldn’t feel as if she’s worthy of Han anymore, as he displays signs throughout the movie that he has a strong moral compass and would never kill someone senselessly.

Anyway, their conversation is interrupted when the Cloud Riders once again appear. They’ve been secretly tailing them throughout the movie.  At first, Han tries to bluff his way out of the situation, telling Enfys Nest that they have an entire armada on board the Millennium Falcon, waiting for his signal to attack them, but that bluff is quickly deflated when Lando, who had slunk back to the Millennium Falcon earlier, flies off, leaving Han, Tobias, Chewbacca and Qi’ra stranded.  But this is when the first twist of the movie comes.  When Han and company state that Drydon Vos is on his way to claim the coaxium, Enfys Nest reveals herself as a young teenage girl.  It turns out she and her band all were survivors of clans that the Crimson Dawn attacked and slaughtered.  And that the reason why they’ve been attacking and tailing the protagonists is because they knew that Drydon Vos would only use the coaxium to lay waste to even more villages, and they’d wanted to prevent him from doing so.  In other words, the Cloud Riders were the good guys the whole time.

Han, upon hearing Enfys Nest’s backstory, begins to feel sympathetic to her and her group.  As a result, he decides to double cross Drydon Vos by giving him vials of fake coaxium while giving the real stuff to the Cloud Riders.  When he reveals this plan to Tobias, the older man decides that he’s not going to stick around as the double cross might go wrong.  Despite his earlier insistence that it’s pointless to run from Drydon Vos, he states he’s going to risk it now.  However, this turns out to be a lie, as it’s later revealed that he was actually going on ahead to tip Drydon Vos off about the deception.  So when Han, Chewbacca and Qi’ra bring the chest of fake coaxium to the crime boss, he already knows that he’s being deceived, and has even sent his men to ambush the Cloud Riders before they could leave with the coaxium.  But then, Han reveals he’d already anticipated Tobias’ betrayal.  And as such, when the goons attack the Cloud Riders, they only find empty chests. Because the real coaxium is in the chest Han brought to Drydon Vos.

And this is when the movie gets to be a bit dizzying.  Because once he finds out that the real coaxium is there, Tobias decides to claim it for his own, drawing a blaster on everyone.  He ends up taking Chewbacca hostage, forcing him to carry the chest of coaxium for him.  Admittedly, this doesn’t make much sense.  Chewbacca is a Wookiee.  One we’d previously seen ripping off someone’s arms.  You can’t tell me he couldn’t have easily overpowered Tobias here.

Regardless, Tobias and Chewbacca leave with the coaxium.  Once they’re gone, a full-on fight breaks out between Han and Drydon Vos, with Han using the blaster he’d gotten from Tobias earlier in the film and Drydon Vos wielding these molten duel knives.  After this fight sequence goes on for a little bit, Qi’ra enters the fray, seemingly coming to Drydon Vos’ defense by pointing some kind of split sword at Han.  But then, she turns on Drydon Vos, stabbing him clean through.  

After Drydon Vos’ death, Qi’ra urges Han to go after Tobias, telling him to get the coaxium to the Cloud Raiders.  She refrains from going with him, however, stating that she’ll catch up to him later. However, after Han leaves, Qi’ra reveals she has no intention of rejoining him, as she takes Drydon’ Vos’ ring, which I suppose was a symbol of his rank in the Crimson Dawn.  I guess that, now that he’s dead, Qi’ra is taking over his position.  However, it’s then revealed that Drydon Vos wasn’t the highest ranking member of the Crimson Dawn, because Qi’ra uses the ring to contact the true leader of the criminal syndicate, giving him a cover story that Drydon Vos was killed by Tobias and that she was the only one who survived the assault.  At first, the identity of the Crimson Dawn leader is hidden by the hood he was wearing.  But when the hood is lowered, the mysterious figure is revealed to be Darth Maul.

Wait, WHAT?! But…how?  He’s dead!  We saw him die in Phantom Menace!  He got sliced in two and then fell down a deep pit.   How could anyone have survived that?!  And before anyone can try to argue this by saying it could have been a different Dathomirian?  No, it’s not.  It’s Darth Maul.  I even checked the end credits, and they clearly stated that this was indeed Maul. How in Coruscant did this guy survive getting split in half and falling down a bottomless pit?  Are they going to try and claim Palpatine survived after the events of Return of the Jedi, too?   Seriously, first it was Red Skull appearing in Infinity War, and now this!  I’d like an explanation for this, please!

Anyway, Darth Maul orders Qi’ra to meet him on his home planet, where he plans to keep a much closer eye on her.  Whether or not he knows she wasn’t complelty honest with him is anyone’s guess. Meanwhile, Han catches up to Tobias and Chewbacca, confronting the former over the matter of the coaxium.  (Not entirely sure how Han managed to get ahead of them as Tobias had a considerable head start, but oh well.)  In response, Tobias starts to reach for his blaster, but then makes the mistake of going off on this whole spiel about how Han needs to learn a lessson.  Han, however, doesn’t mess around with formalities and fatally shoots Tobias. With his final words, Tobias commends Han for not hesitating to do what he had to, also while lamenting that he never got the chance to pursue his dream to be a musician.

In the aftermath of the adventure, Han and Chewbacca willingly pass the coaxium over to Enfys Nest, who reveals she plans to deliver it to the Rebel Alliance.  She suggests that Han consider joining the resistance himself, but Han declines, stating that it’s highly unlikely that he’ll change his mind on the matter.  Though those who have seen the original trilogy already know that he’ll eventually change his tune.  In gratitude for his help, Enfys Nest gifts Han and Chewbacca with a small vial of coaxium.

Later on, Han and Chewbacca manage to locate Lando again, this time on some kind of lush jungle planet.  Needless to say, Han is fully ready to give Lando a piece of his mind about how he’d stranded them all on Savareen.  But that’s when he catches a brief glimpse of the card dispenser mechanism affixed to Lando’s wrist.  Right always, he realizes that Lando had cheated in their earlier game of Sabacc. Deciding to get one up on him, Han challenges Lando to a rematch, offering his vial of coaxium as a starting wager.  Lando readily accepts, not realizing until the final round of their game that Han manages to swipe the cards he was concealing up his sleeve.  As a result, Han is able to win the Millennium Falcon fair and square, a fact that Lando begrudgingly accepts.  And so, with their newly won ship, Han and Chewbacca set off, deciding to set a course for Tatooine, as Tobias had mentioned earlier that there was a big shot gangster putting together a crew of smugglers on that particular planet.  While it’s never specifically stated, I suppose we can only conclude they’re referring to Jabba.  Which explains how Han and Chewbacca got involved with him in the first place. And so, the movie ends with the pair flying off, with the Millennium Falcon jumping into light speed.

All in all, I think this was a really good origin story for Han Solo.  And, dare I say it, I actually enjoyed this movie more than The Last Jedi.  Not that The Last Jedi was an awful movie, of course.  But my attitude after seeing that one was more or less ‘eh, okay, I guess I’ll see you guys again in a few years.’  With this movie, on the other hand, I really wanted to see what happened next.  What happened to Qi’ra?  Is she actually a Sith Lord training under Darth Maul?  Did she and Han ever see each other again?  Obviously, something happens that enables Han to decide to move on from her, considering he eventually pursues a relationship with Leia. While Han is sometimes seen as a womanizer by some members of the fandom, that reputation always seemed rather undeserved, as he appears to be more of a one-woman man.  So did Qi’ra end up dying at some point between now and A New Hope?  (I suppose it’s possible she ended up horribly betraying him somehow somewhere down the line, but the fact that Han obviously held on to the golden pair of dice that they kept passing back and forth throughout the movie makes it seem like he still regarded her memory with fondness, so I doubt anything went sour between them. ) Also, is that all there was to the backstory between Han and Lando’s friendship, or did they cross paths a few more times over the years?  The movie gave us this open ending that left you with a lot of questions, but not to the point where it felt as if the plotpoints were left unresolved.  It’s quite rare to find a movie that can achieve that sort of balance.  Let’s just say that if they turned this movie into a trilogy as well, you certainly wouldn’t hear me complain.

As for the actor who portrayed the younger version of Han, I think he did a good job. Obviously, nobody was going to live up to Harrison Ford.  But there were moments when I looked at Alden Ehrenreich and I really thought he looked like a younger version of Han.  And I thought the way they presented this younger version of him to be quite good. Sure, the Han of the original trilogy made a clear effort at portraying himself as a scoundrel, but at the same time, it was always evident that he was a good man at his core.  At the end of the day, he was the one who would ultimately do the right thing, because he can’t completely turn off his moral compass when he sees people in trouble.  It’s why he came back at the moment of truth during the battle of the first Death Star. I also liked how the movie left it rather vague over whether Chewbacca was searching for his family or just his tribe. I’m not entirely sure, but I’m pretty sure that bit was made to appeal to both the fans who consider the infamous holiday special to be canon and those who refuse to acknowledge its existence. (Oh, don’t worry- I’ll post my review to that one on the 22nd.)

Though, I will admit it was a bit off-putting that the two characters I particularly liked- Rio and L3- were both killed off.  Though, at least we have the knowledge that L3 will live on in a sense, which does help soften the blow.  She’s now forever a part of the Millennium Falcon’s mainframe.  Though, even if she wasn’t, the untimely deaths of my two favorite characters in this particular instalment of the franchise wasn’t enough to taint my enjoyment of the movie.  After all, character death isn’t a foreign concept in these Star Wars anthology movies.

On that note, Rouge One will be the subject of next week’s review.  And then, it’s on to the original trilogy.

trail.content:
Okay, wow! This movie was unbelievable! Remember how we can all pretty much agree that The Last Jedi had moments that kinda fell flat?  Well, I think I figured out the reason why.  It was because they were putting all their effort into this movie.  Now, just to warn everyone- because this is a review, I WILL be spoiling the plot of this movie.  So if you plan on reading beyond this point before you actually go see the movie yourself, then that’s on you.

The movie opens on some run-down planet called Corellia, where this giant sentient millipede-like alien called Lady Proxima essentially runs the show.  Because of the corruption that now runs rampant after the formation of the Galactic Empire, a lot of crime syndicates have been able to take root, and Lady Proxima is no exception.  She runs this thieves guild on Corellia where she basically abducts children and forces them to steal stuff for her in exchange for food and shelter. Right away, we are shown that the teenaged Han is one of the young thieves under Lady Proxima’s control. Unfortunately, the latest mission he was sent on, which involved delivering a cache of coaxium, a highly valued kind of fuel in exchange for money, didn’t exactly go well and he was forced to run for his life, leaving the money he was supposed to retrieve behind. However, he did manage to swipe a small vial of coaxium for himself.  He shows this to his girlfriend, Qi'ra, who also lives under Lady Proxima’s thumb. Han states that he plans to trade the vial of coaxium for passage off Corellia for the both of them, so they can live in freedom.  Han also reveals his aspiration to be a top-notch pilot with his own ship, a goal he plans to achieve once he and Qi’ra escape Corellia and Lady Proxima.

Before Han could put his plan into action, however Lady Proxima’s goons appear, apprehending Han.  He’s forcibly taken before Lady Proxima, who is not pleased that Han failed his most recent mission by not bringing her the money he was supposed to pick up.  As punishment for his transgression, she is all set to have him whipped and beaten until he learns his lesson and starts being completely obedient to her.  This prompts Qi’ra to try and come to his defense, but Han comes up with a plan on the spot.  He threatens to blow everyone up with a thermal detonator that he just happened to have on him.  (Which was an obvious callback to that one scene in Return of the Jedi.  You all know the one I mean.)  Of course, Lady Proxima isn’t stupid and realizes that Han is just holding a rock. But Han just basically shrugs and hurls the rock up at the roof, which creates a large hole that sunlight pours through.  Lady Proxima, it turns out, does not like the light, as contact with the sunlight will give her an instant sunburn, and thus has no choice but to retreat into her water-filled chamber.

Taking advantage of the resulting turmoil, Han grabs hold of Qi’ra and the pair attempt to make their getaway, utilizing a land speeder Han had commandeered in the first scene of the movie.  After a whole car chase scene, Han and Qi’ra manage to make it to Corellia’s spaceport, which is filled with people trying to make it off the planet by boarding a transport that’s scheduled to leave soon.  Right away, it’s established that this is a risky place to be, as a lot of the people there are trying to sneak off the planet to freedom, with Imperial Guards and Stormtroopers standing at the ready to apprehend people who don’t have the proper documentation.  At one point, we even see a group of children being forcibly separated from their parents. (Not sure if this was meant to be taken as social commentary with political subtext, but it was still unsettling to witness.)  Trying to act casual, Han and Qi’ra get into the ticket agent line, all too aware of the fact that Lady Proxima’s goons are searching the premises for them.  When it’s their turn to present their travel papers to the Imperial Guard on duty, Han admits they don’t have any, but manages to bribe the guard with the vial of coaxium, stating that they’ll hand it over to her if they’re allowed through the gates.  Unable to resist the bribe, the Imperial Guard opens the gate to allow them through.  But just as the pair are in the process of walking through the gate, Lady Proxima’s goons appear out of nowhere and apprehend Qi’ra, just as the gates slam shut. As such, she and Han are forcibly separated, and Han can only watch as Qi’ra is dragged off.  As she’s taken away, Han calls out to her, vowing that he will come back for her as soon as he can.

However, before he can uphold his promise, Han realizes that he’s going to need a ship of his own.  In the hopes of earning enough money to purchase a ship, he ends up volunteering to join the Empire by enlisting in Imperial Navy.  When he goes to the recruitment office, he confesses to the Imperial Recruitment Officer that he has no surname.  As such, the Recruitment Officer decides to give him the name Han Solo.

The action then fast-forwards to three years later.  Han is now serving as an infantryman and is placed among an Imperial squadron fighting on an extremely muddy planet called Mimban.  It comes out that he was kicked out of the Imperial Flight Academy due to an inability to follow orders without question.  Now, it might just have been me, but for some reason, the whole battlefront on Mimban made me think of World War One, and the whole trench warfare they utilized.  Though I’m not sure if that was intentional.

While he’s on Mimban, Han spots a small group among the infantrymen.  Right away, he is able to surmise that they’re actually impostors who infiltrated the infantry in order to steal one of the dropships, particularly when one of them doesn’t seem to realize that his uniform indicates he’s the highest ranking soldier among them until it’s directly pointed out to him. Han ends up confronting them about this, attempting to blackmail them into letting him join them when they make their way off the planet.  However, the leader of the group, Tobias Beckett, ends up having Han arrested for attempted desertion instead, telling the arresting officers that Han is a liar and that they shouldn’t believe a word he says.  Which pretty much takes care of Han’s threats to expose them as impostors.

The arresting officers sentence Han to be fed to the ‘beast’ they have been keeping imprisoned.  When Han is tossed into grate covered pit, it’s revealed, to nobody’s shock, that the ‘beast’ is actually Chewbacca.  Initially, Chewbacca doesn’t hesitate to attack Han, possibly embittered by how long the Imperial Army has kept him starved and chained up.  But he instantly relents when Han reveals that he can speak Wookiee.  At least, to an extent.  Han isn’t exactly fluent in Chewbacca’s native language, but he knows enough to convey his plan of escape to Chewbacca.  Han’s plan involves them staging a fight for the entertainment of the Imperial Officers that are overseeing the proceedings. But instead of punching Han, Chewbacca will be hitting the support beam that is holding up the grate covering the opening of the pit.  The plan ultimately succeeds, enabling Han and Chewbacca to climb out.  But the pair are still chained together, which leads to a brief argument of which direction they’ll head off in. In the end, Han convinces Chewbacca to trust him, stating that he has friends that are in the process of leaving Mimban.  All they have to do is continue their alliance long enough reach their shuttle before they leave.  After that, they’d be free to go their separate ways at any time.  Chewbacca ends up agreeing to that plan, and two hurry off to try and catch up to Tobias and his team.  They arrive at the launch pad just in time to see Tobias’ ship taking off, but when Tobias and his allies see that Han has managed to get away, and is now accompanied by a Wookiee, it’d decided that they will allow the pair to board the ship.  More specifically, Tobias and the group’s Alien member, Rio, (who apparently has a deep appreciation for Wookiees) decide it’s a good idea.  The female of the trio, Val, isn’t exactly on board with admitting a pair of rookies into their operation, but she ultimately goes along with it, realizing that she’s outvoted.

Now that Han and Chewbacca have joined Tobias’ team, they are informed of their plan to pull off a train heist in order to make off with a shipment of that fuel source, coaxium.  The night before their heist, the group has this whole campfire bonding moment, with Han stating that his ultimate goal is still the same as it was at the start of the movie.  He wants to earn enough money to buy a ship, so he can return to Corellia and save Qi’ra. This scene also serves to inform the audience that, after the rise of the Galactic Empire, the Imperial Forces managed to overthrow Kashyyyk, and a good number of Wookiees were taken prisoner. It’s stated that Chewbacca’s family, or at least his tribe, were among the captured Wookies, so his ultimate goal is to find them and free them.  Apart from those character development moments, nothing much else happens during this scene.  But it is indicated that Tobias and Val are romantically involved.

The following morning, Han, Chewbacca, Tobias, Val and Rio proceed with their train heist. However, the robbery is interrupted by the appearance of a band of space pirates called the Cloud Riders, who are led by an armored figure known as Enfys Nest.  This leads to a whole action sequence, in which both groups try to claim the coaxium.  Due in part to the interference of the Cloud Riders, Val and Rio are both killed. And, when Han, Tobias and Chewbacca try to make off with the spoils, Han ends up defying Tobias orders and releases the cargo, resulting in it getting destroyed.  This was because the Cloud Riders also had attached tethers to the crate of coaxium, resulting in them having a tug-of-war of sorts.  And Han realized that if he didn’t release their hold on the coaxium, then he wouldn’t be able to maneuver their ship around a mountain in time.  So it was pretty much a choice between the coaxium and their lives.  Honestly, I think that decision was very much in character for Han.  Isn’t that what will one day get him into trouble with Jabba?

On a side note, I have to admit I really liked Rio.  I thought he was a fun character, especially with his strange love for Wookiees.  It was a bit like Maz from the new trilogy. The moment he first appeared, I instantly decided that I liked him.  So it really stinks that he was killed off after such a short amount of screentime. Shame we couldn’t see more of him.

In the aftermath of the failed heist, Tobias rounds on Han, angrily punching him for losing the coaxium.  Here, it’s revealed that Tobias and his late teammates weren’t actually stealing the coaxium for themselves.  Instead, they had been hired by Drydon Vos, the leader of a criminal syndicate known as the Crimson Dawn.  Now that the crate of coaxium is lost, Tobias is fearful for his life, as Drydon Vos is not known to be very understanding or forgiving.  And he knows that he won’t be able to run, as Drydon Vos would undoubtedly succeed in locating him, no matter where he might try to hide.  In the hopes of convincing Drydon Vos to give him another chance, Tobias ends up going to seek an audience with him on the mob boss’ space yacht.  But before he leaves, Tobias informs Han and Chewbacca that this will be their last chance to get out of this mess.  Because Drydon Vos currently has no idea that either of them even exist and will never know they were even involved with this if they back out now.  But Han insists on seeing this through to the end, as he knows he can’t pass up on this chance to get the money for this job.  Chewbacca also agrees to stick around.  Maybe because he feels that this would eventually help him locate the other Wookiees that were abducted and taken away from Kashyyyk.

When they arrive at Drydon Vos’ space yacht, Tobias announces their presence to one of Drydon Vos’ goons.  While waiting around to be summoned, Tobias and Chewbacca head off to get some drinks at the bar while Han decides to make his way to the edge of the crowd to simply look out the window.  But then, someone approaches him and taps his shoulder.  To Han’s shock and amazement, he sees the person who has joined him at the window is none other than Qi’ra, his girlfriend from Corellia!  Han is overjoyed to see her again, and he immediately starts to apologize for not coming back for her, stating that he really had planned on doing so the moment he’d been able to buy his own ship.  But Qi’ra waves away his apology, stating that it’s all in the past and she doesn’t resent him for not being able to keep his promise to her, also pointing out that he would have been killed if he hadn’t taken advantage of his chance to get off Corellia.  It turns out that, after she and Han were separated three years ago, Qi’ra somehow became entangled into the Crimson Dawn and is essentially bound to Drydon Vos now.

But the two are not given much of a chance to catch up, because that’s when Tobias returns, announcing their meeting with Drydon Vos has been approved.  Needless to say, Drydon Vos is not pleased when he finds out Tobias did not bring the shipment of coaxium that he’d requested and is all set to kill him for this, unless Tobias can tell him exactly how he plans to make it up to him.  Tobias therefore offers to locate and steal some coaxium from a different source.  Of course, this is easier said than done as coaxium is still super-rare, with the Empire holding a cartel on the market. But Han has an idea- they go right to the source and steal unprocessed coaxium from the mines on the planet Kessel. Of course, this is an extremely risky plan, as unprocessed coaxium is extremely volatile, and if it’s not processed within a certain time frame, then it will explode.  Once again, however, Han has an idea.  There’s apparently a processing plant that’s not controlled by the Empire, located on the planet Savareen.  Although this plan is still extremely risky, as it would require them to make the infamous Kessel Run in less than twenty parsecs.  And yes, I know that a parsec is a unit of distance and not time.  But maybe the implication is that the average Kessel Run spans a distance that’s over twenty parsecs, and to make the journey in less than twenty parsects is synonymous with finding a way to travel from Maine to California (a trip that should span 3,247 miles) in only 1,000 miles.  But then again, this is just me trying to make sense over a line that was probably only meant to give nerds something to harp on.

In any event, Drydon Vos ultimately agrees to Han’s plan and, in what I’m guessing was an attempt to make sure that Tobias, Han and Chewbacca follow through and don’t just try to run, he has Qi’ra accompany them.  But before they can go off to steal the coaxium, they have to locate a suitably fast ship that would enable them to make the trip. Fortunately, Qi’ra knows where to find such a ship.  She leads the group to this place on a snowy planet called Vandor that kinda looks like a crashed luxury starship that has been converted into a gambling hall. There, they encounter the smooth-talking Lando Calrissian, who boasts that his ship is the fastest one in existence. He’s accompanied by L3-37, a female Piloting Droid that Lando apparently had custom made to be his co-pilot. While I’m sure some people might disagree with me on this, I say L3 was the best character in this movie.  Her claim to fame was the fact that she’s a fierce advocate for Droid rights.  When we first meet her, she’s angrily protesting a Droid battle ring that’s being held in the gambling hall, trying to reason with one of the Droids being used in the fighting and then getting into an argument with the Droid’s owner.   To be honest, I totally see her point in regards to her crusade.  Even though Droids are clearly manmade, they are still programed with artificial intelligence, and they all seem to have their own personalities.  It does present an interesting debate over what it means to be considered ‘alive.’ And when you think of it, there does seem to be a prevailing discrimination towards Droids.  For instance, it seems like a lot of eateries won’t serve Droids.  And then there’s Obi-Wan’s comment in Attack of the Clones, in which he more or less stated that he didn’t thing Droids were capable of independent thought.  So, it could be argued that Droids are largely treated as robot slaves in the Star Wars universe, with each type of Droid being automatically assigned a particular task from the moment they’re activated and never given the opportunity to rise above the task they were issued upon their creation.  For instance, I don’t recall seeing any Droids serving on the Galactic Senate during the prequel trilogy.

Anyway, Han approaches Lando, with Tobias, Chewbacca and Qi’ra watching with the rest of the crowd, to ask him about his ship.  Lando states he won it in a game of Sabacc, which is basically this world’s equivalent to poker.  Han kinda chuckles at that, vocally wondering what kind of man bets his ship in a card game. Eventually, he asks to be dealt into the game of Sabacc that Lando is currently playing with a handful of Aliens. Now, the build up to this moment is rather strange.  Because before this scene, we had been given no sort of context as to what Han’s gambling skill is like.  Is he actually really good when it comes to gambling?  Has he ever gambled or played Sabacc before?  But I guess he’s quite good, because he manages to stay in the game after everyone else has folded.  So, in the end, it’s just him against Lando.  In the final round, Lando ends up wagering his ship, which, of course, ends up being the Millennium Falcon.  To counter this wager, Han also bets his own ship.  Which we know doesn’t actually exist.  However, Lando ends up winning the game because he was cheating by hiding a stash of cards up his sleeve.  After the game, Lando approaches the group to ask where he can pick up the ship he supposedly won off of Han.  Only to be told that it wasn’t there.   As a consolation prize, they fill him in on their plan to steal unprocessed coaxium from the mines on Kessel.  They tell Lando that if he provides his ship for the heist, then they will give him a cut of the money they’ll get for the coaxium.  Lando doesn’t seem to be completely thrilled with this arrangement, but he ultimately agrees to it, especially when he sees Tobias is involved. Apparently, Tobias had previously brought about the death of somebody Lando owed a lot of money to, so Lando is grateful towards him for indirectly freeing him from his debt.

And they’re off to Kessel.  Along the way, we get a few scenes of the characters just being characters.  Qi’ra is exploring the Falcon, finding that Lando seems to have a thing for capes.  She also has a moment with Han which leads to them passionately making out, only for them to be interrupted by Tobias, who counsels Han that he’d do well to not trust Qi’ra so much, and that it’s best to just expect everyone might betray him.  Tobias and Chewbacca also play around with that holographic chess board thing (with Chewbacca losing, much to his frustration.)  And we also get a whole ‘girl talk’ moment with Qi’ra and L3, with L3 observing that Han is still in love with Qi’ra.  It’s at this point that we’re told that Lando and L3’s relationship is a bit more than just one between pilot and co-pilot, and it’s heavily implied they have a sexual relationship.  So I guess Lando is pansexual?  Okay, that’s pretty interesting.  I don’t think we see many pansexual characters featured in the media, do we?

Eventually, they reach Kessel and, in order to infiltrate the mine, Qi’ra, Tobias and L3 masquerade as human traffickers and present Han and Chewbacca as new workers for the mine.  And you might notice that Tobias is wearing the same disguise Lando will eventually wear in the first half of Return of the Jedi.  Speaking of Lando, he’s apparently hanging back on the Millennium Falcon to make another entry in his personal ‘Lando Chronicles.’  I guess we’re supposed to conclude that Lando is a bit full of himself.

Upon being brought into the mines, Han and Chewbacca both reveal that their restraints were not locked, and they immediately break free and overpower the two guards bringing them down the mine elevator  (with Chewbacca actually ripping off somebody’s arms.)  Meanwhile, up in the control room, Qi’ra gets to work on upholding her part of the plan, which involves her and Tobias taking out the mine foreman and guards so L3 could take over the control room’s console, in order to gain access to the mine’s security footage and use that to direct Han and Chewbacca to the chamber the coaxium is stored in.  However, in the process, L3 finds she can’t stand to turn a blind eye to the fact that Droids are being used to run the mine, especially when she spots a restraining bolt affixed to one of the Astromech Droids. She ends up starting a complete riot by getting the Droids to free one other, which leads to all the other mine workers rising up and attempting to fight their way to freedom.  Thankfully, this creates a distraction that makes it possible for Han to locate the coaxium vault.  Amidst the resulting turmoil, Han starts to wheel them out to the Millennium Falcon.  Chewbacca, on the other hand, briefly went off on his own when he spots some Wookiees laboring in the mines because he recognized them as some of the Wookiees that were captured alongside him.  But he ends up rejoining Han just in time to help him get the coaxium to the Millennium Falcon, with the other Wookiees helping load the canisters onto the ship. And, when given the choice between staying with his Wookiee brethren or sticking with Han and the others, Chewbacca ultimately chooses the latter.  Most likely because he’s grown to genuinely consider Han as a friend.

This whole prison break/coaxium heist quickly shifts into a huge gun battle as the mine workers try to escape.  During the fight, L3 gets gunned down and Lando is also hit when he runs out to retrieve her. Sadly, while Lando only ends up with an injured shoulder, L3 is damaged beyond repair and ends up dying in Lando’s arms.  

With Lando out of commission and L3 gone, Han and Chewbacca (who admits to have gained some piloting experience during the 190 years he’s been alive) are the only ones capable of flying the ship away from Kessel.  Unfortunately, their path back to Savareen is being blocked by an Imperial brigade, led by a Star Destroyer that immediately sends a fleet of TIE Fighters at them.  It’s speculated that the Imperial patrol had heard about the uprising on Kessel and had come to put an end to it.  While they eventually manage to get rid of the TIE Fighters, through a combination of Tobias manning the ship’s gun and a risky move by Han, they realize they lost a considerable amount of time, as the coaxium is already starting to destabilize. In a desperate attempt at making it to Savareen in time, Han suggests taking a short cut through a cloudy ‘tunnel’ inside the nebula cloud they’re traveling past.  At first, everyone feels this is crazy, as entering that cloud tunnel would most likely kill them, as it contains a high number of plasma storms. But Han points out that their current position is no better.  In order to try and increase their chances at making through alive, it’s decided to install the memory banks/navigational archives of L3 into the Millennium Falcon’s motherboard.  It was established earlier that L3 was programed with impeccable navigational skills. Once L3’s programing is fully installed within the Millennium Falcon, they are able to navigate their way through the nebula cloud tunnel, despite some trouble with a Space Kraken and a black hole of some kind.  They evade the Space Kraken by launching off the Millennium Falcon’s escape pod to create a diversion (which explains why the front of the ship wound up with that recognizable shape.)  And to escape the black hole, they use a single drop of the coaxium to power the ship’s fusion reactor resulting in the Millennium Falcon getting a major speed boost that frees it from the pull of the black hole

Finally, they manage to make it to Savareen.  And thanks to Han’s plan to travel through the nebula cloud and L3’s memory within the Millennium Falcon, they made the Kessel Run in 12 parsects. While they’re getting the coaxium processed, and for Drydon Vos to arrive, Han and Qi’ra have another scene together.  Han tries to convince Qi’ra to come away with him when this is all over, but Qi’ra tells him that’s not possible due to her involvement with the Crimson Dawn.  I guess the implication is that the Crimson Dawn is like the Mafia- once you’re in it, you’re in it for life.  She tells Han that his feelings for her would change if he had any inking of the things she’s done as part of the Crimson Dawn. Which I guess is meant to imply that she was utilized as their hit woman, tasked with brutally murdering anyone they ordered her to.  If that’s the case, I can see why Qi’ra wouldn’t feel as if she’s worthy of Han anymore, as he displays signs throughout the movie that he has a strong moral compass and would never kill someone senselessly.

Anyway, their conversation is interrupted when the Cloud Riders once again appear. They’ve been secretly tailing them throughout the movie.  At first, Han tries to bluff his way out of the situation, telling Enfys Nest that they have an entire armada on board the Millennium Falcon, waiting for his signal to attack them, but that bluff is quickly deflated when Lando, who had slunk back to the Millennium Falcon earlier, flies off, leaving Han, Tobias, Chewbacca and Qi’ra stranded.  But this is when the first twist of the movie comes.  When Han and company state that Drydon Vos is on his way to claim the coaxium, Enfys Nest reveals herself as a young teenage girl.  It turns out she and her band all were survivors of clans that the Crimson Dawn attacked and slaughtered.  And that the reason why they’ve been attacking and tailing the protagonists is because they knew that Drydon Vos would only use the coaxium to lay waste to even more villages, and they’d wanted to prevent him from doing so.  In other words, the Cloud Riders were the good guys the whole time.

Han, upon hearing Enfys Nest’s backstory, begins to feel sympathetic to her and her group.  As a result, he decides to double cross Drydon Vos by giving him vials of fake coaxium while giving the real stuff to the Cloud Riders.  When he reveals this plan to Tobias, the older man decides that he’s not going to stick around as the double cross might go wrong.  Despite his earlier insistence that it’s pointless to run from Drydon Vos, he states he’s going to risk it now.  However, this turns out to be a lie, as it’s later revealed that he was actually going on ahead to tip Drydon Vos off about the deception.  So when Han, Chewbacca and Qi’ra bring the chest of fake coaxium to the crime boss, he already knows that he’s being deceived, and has even sent his men to ambush the Cloud Riders before they could leave with the coaxium.  But then, Han reveals he’d already anticipated Tobias’ betrayal.  And as such, when the goons attack the Cloud Riders, they only find empty chests. Because the real coaxium is in the chest Han brought to Drydon Vos.

And this is when the movie gets to be a bit dizzying.  Because once he finds out that the real coaxium is there, Tobias decides to claim it for his own, drawing a blaster on everyone.  He ends up taking Chewbacca hostage, forcing him to carry the chest of coaxium for him.  Admittedly, this doesn’t make much sense.  Chewbacca is a Wookiee.  One we’d previously seen ripping off someone’s arms.  You can’t tell me he couldn’t have easily overpowered Tobias here.

Regardless, Tobias and Chewbacca leave with the coaxium.  Once they’re gone, a full-on fight breaks out between Han and Drydon Vos, with Han using the blaster he’d gotten from Tobias earlier in the film and Drydon Vos wielding these molten duel knives.  After this fight sequence goes on for a little bit, Qi’ra enters the fray, seemingly coming to Drydon Vos’ defense by pointing some kind of split sword at Han.  But then, she turns on Drydon Vos, stabbing him clean through.  

After Drydon Vos’ death, Qi’ra urges Han to go after Tobias, telling him to get the coaxium to the Cloud Raiders.  She refrains from going with him, however, stating that she’ll catch up to him later. However, after Han leaves, Qi’ra reveals she has no intention of rejoining him, as she takes Drydon’ Vos’ ring, which I suppose was a symbol of his rank in the Crimson Dawn.  I guess that, now that he’s dead, Qi’ra is taking over his position.  However, it’s then revealed that Drydon Vos wasn’t the highest ranking member of the Crimson Dawn, because Qi’ra uses the ring to contact the true leader of the criminal syndicate, giving him a cover story that Drydon Vos was killed by Tobias and that she was the only one who survived the assault.  At first, the identity of the Crimson Dawn leader is hidden by the hood he was wearing.  But when the hood is lowered, the mysterious figure is revealed to be Darth Maul.

Wait, WHAT?! But…how?  He’s dead!  We saw him die in Phantom Menace!  He got sliced in two and then fell down a deep pit.   How could anyone have survived that?!  And before anyone can try to argue this by saying it could have been a different Dathomirian?  No, it’s not.  It’s Darth Maul.  I even checked the end credits, and they clearly stated that this was indeed Maul. How in Coruscant did this guy survive getting split in half and falling down a bottomless pit?  Are they going to try and claim Palpatine survived after the events of Return of the Jedi, too?   Seriously, first it was Red Skull appearing in Infinity War, and now this!  I’d like an explanation for this, please!

Anyway, Darth Maul orders Qi’ra to meet him on his home planet, where he plans to keep a much closer eye on her.  Whether or not he knows she wasn’t complelty honest with him is anyone’s guess. Meanwhile, Han catches up to Tobias and Chewbacca, confronting the former over the matter of the coaxium.  (Not entirely sure how Han managed to get ahead of them as Tobias had a considerable head start, but oh well.)  In response, Tobias starts to reach for his blaster, but then makes the mistake of going off on this whole spiel about how Han needs to learn a lessson.  Han, however, doesn’t mess around with formalities and fatally shoots Tobias. With his final words, Tobias commends Han for not hesitating to do what he had to, also while lamenting that he never got the chance to pursue his dream to be a musician.

In the aftermath of the adventure, Han and Chewbacca willingly pass the coaxium over to Enfys Nest, who reveals she plans to deliver it to the Rebel Alliance.  She suggests that Han consider joining the resistance himself, but Han declines, stating that it’s highly unlikely that he’ll change his mind on the matter.  Though those who have seen the original trilogy already know that he’ll eventually change his tune.  In gratitude for his help, Enfys Nest gifts Han and Chewbacca with a small vial of coaxium.

Later on, Han and Chewbacca manage to locate Lando again, this time on some kind of lush jungle planet.  Needless to say, Han is fully ready to give Lando a piece of his mind about how he’d stranded them all on Savareen.  But that’s when he catches a brief glimpse of the card dispenser mechanism affixed to Lando’s wrist.  Right always, he realizes that Lando had cheated in their earlier game of Sabacc. Deciding to get one up on him, Han challenges Lando to a rematch, offering his vial of coaxium as a starting wager.  Lando readily accepts, not realizing until the final round of their game that Han manages to swipe the cards he was concealing up his sleeve.  As a result, Han is able to win the Millennium Falcon fair and square, a fact that Lando begrudgingly accepts.  And so, with their newly won ship, Han and Chewbacca set off, deciding to set a course for Tatooine, as Tobias had mentioned earlier that there was a big shot gangster putting together a crew of smugglers on that particular planet.  While it’s never specifically stated, I suppose we can only conclude they’re referring to Jabba.  Which explains how Han and Chewbacca got involved with him in the first place. And so, the movie ends with the pair flying off, with the Millennium Falcon jumping into light speed.

All in all, I think this was a really good origin story for Han Solo.  And, dare I say it, I actually enjoyed this movie more than The Last Jedi.  Not that The Last Jedi was an awful movie, of course.  But my attitude after seeing that one was more or less ‘eh, okay, I guess I’ll see you guys again in a few years.’  With this movie, on the other hand, I really wanted to see what happened next.  What happened to Qi’ra?  Is she actually a Sith Lord training under Darth Maul?  Did she and Han ever see each other again?  Obviously, something happens that enables Han to decide to move on from her, considering he eventually pursues a relationship with Leia. While Han is sometimes seen as a womanizer by some members of the fandom, that reputation always seemed rather undeserved, as he appears to be more of a one-woman man.  So did Qi’ra end up dying at some point between now and A New Hope?  (I suppose it’s possible she ended up horribly betraying him somehow somewhere down the line, but the fact that Han obviously held on to the golden pair of dice that they kept passing back and forth throughout the movie makes it seem like he still regarded her memory with fondness, so I doubt anything went sour between them. ) Also, is that all there was to the backstory between Han and Lando’s friendship, or did they cross paths a few more times over the years?  The movie gave us this open ending that left you with a lot of questions, but not to the point where it felt as if the plotpoints were left unresolved.  It’s quite rare to find a movie that can achieve that sort of balance.  Let’s just say that if they turned this movie into a trilogy as well, you certainly wouldn’t hear me complain.

As for the actor who portrayed the younger version of Han, I think he did a good job. Obviously, nobody was going to live up to Harrison Ford.  But there were moments when I looked at Alden Ehrenreich and I really thought he looked like a younger version of Han.  And I thought the way they presented this younger version of him to be quite good. Sure, the Han of the original trilogy made a clear effort at portraying himself as a scoundrel, but at the same time, it was always evident that he was a good man at his core.  At the end of the day, he was the one who would ultimately do the right thing, because he can’t completely turn off his moral compass when he sees people in trouble.  It’s why he came back at the moment of truth during the battle of the first Death Star. I also liked how the movie left it rather vague over whether Chewbacca was searching for his family or just his tribe. I’m not entirely sure, but I’m pretty sure that bit was made to appeal to both the fans who consider the infamous holiday special to be canon and those who refuse to acknowledge its existence. (Oh, don’t worry- I’ll post my review to that one on the 22nd.)

Though, I will admit it was a bit off-putting that the two characters I particularly liked- Rio and L3- were both killed off.  Though, at least we have the knowledge that L3 will live on in a sense, which does help soften the blow.  She’s now forever a part of the Millennium Falcon’s mainframe.  Though, even if she wasn’t, the untimely deaths of my two favorite characters in this particular instalment of the franchise wasn’t enough to taint my enjoyment of the movie.  After all, character death isn’t a foreign concept in these Star Wars anthology movies.

On that note, Rouge One will be the subject of next week’s review.  And then, it’s on to the original trilogy.

trail.content_abstract: Okay, wow! This movie was unbelievable! Remember how we can all pretty much agree that The Last Jedi had moments that kinda fell flat?  Well, I think I figured out the reason why.  It was because they were putting all their effort into this movie.  Now, just to warn everyone- because this is a review, I WILL be spoiling the plot of this movie.  So if you plan on reading beyond this point before you actually go see the movie yourself, then that’s on you.
